content:
While DNA replication is a highly accurate process, errors can occur. These errors are known as mutations, and they can happen spontaneously due to a variety of factors such as errors in DNA replication, exposure to mutagens (environmental factors that can cause mutations), or natural changes in DNA over time. 

Fortunately, cells have multiple mechanisms to detect and repair errors in DNA replication, helping to minimize the impact of mutations on genetic inheritance. One example of these mechanisms is proofreading by DNA polymerase, which checks for errors and corrects them as it elongates the new strand. Another example is the mismatch repair system, which monitors the newly synthesized DNA strands for mismatches or errors and repairs them.

However, sometimes the error rate is not low enough, leading to mutations that can accumulate and cause genetic diseases or other health problems. Moreover, mutations are also a driving force behind evolution as they help to create new genetic variations upon which natural selection acts.
